ll.de: Watch at least one lesson per week and practice your skills daily.

pl.de: Final a comfortable place, listen and follow practices daily.

its.de:
Welcome to the Caring Program for caregivers of people with dementia, based on past research conducted by Photozig, Inc., in collaboration with Stanford University and the Alzheimerâ€™s Association, in addition to other studies. It is funded by the National Institutes on Aging, part of the US National Institutes of Health.

This program provides educational content and suggestions to improve your mindset when providing care. Getting prepared can help you as a caregiver reduce your stress and anxiety.

Relaxation or mindfulness exercises are also included. Try to you find a comfortable, quiet place for each exercise. As they are completed, new ones will be unlocked. Please consider repeating the exercises that you like.

We recommend that you watch one lesson per week, which should take about 10 minutes, and practice one to three relax exercises per day, about 5 minutes each.

This program is for information only. It does not provide any medical advice, diagnosis, treatment, legal, financial, or other professional services advice. Please consult with your doctor before following any exercises of this program.

We hope that you will learn new skills, calm your mind, and enhance your caregiving experience!

This training program teaches new skills to cultivate helpful thinking, direct attention, and nurture a better experience. These skills may help to alleviate stress, bring you to the moment, reduce the tendency to worry, and increase your appreciation for current achievements.

The Lessons contain coping skills on how to deal with difficult caregiving situations, including useful tools, valuable information, and practical tips.

The Exercises may help you tune your mind to the present, observe your body, and bring awareness to the moment. By standing back, you may relax, pause your mind and body, have a clearer view of the situation, and enhance your well-being.

You may learn how to turn off the thinking autopilot, reduce rumination, focus on being in the present to achieve our goals, calm the mind with breathing and relaxation exercises, and improve your overall mood, when nurturing your mind and body.

The caregiver journey can be very isolated. We recommend you get support from family and friends, participate in support groups, and access resources from the Alzheimerâ€™s Association, National Institutes of Health, and other organizations.

There might be some bumps on the road ahead, but remember, you are not alone.

The mind is always working, sometimes in an autopilot mode, driving us around and making us do things without deliberation. Such autopilot can also play a video of things that worry us and cause rumination, anxiety, and stress.

Letting the autopilot control our mind is not helpful since negative thoughts are usually more sticky than positive ones, and that may drive us into a declining spiral of unhappiness, leading to the perception that the world is against us, and life is not so good.

In such cases, we recommend turning the autopilot off, looking at the bright side, and cherishing good moments. A good strategy is to bring your attention to here and now, by practicing mindfulness exercises such as Stopping.

Please follow the Stopping and other exercises three times per day in the next seven days.

When we try to calm our minds, we may get lost with thoughts about past events, present activities, or upcoming plans. They may cause worries, rumination, and unhelpful interpretations.

To avoid this â€œthinking aboutâ€ state, we want to switch to focusing on body sensations during mindfulness exercises, releasing ourselves from these concerning thoughts and connecting to another inner voice that describes our experience, sensations, and feelings.

This quiet voice may enable us to look at unpleasant situations from a different perspective, as an experience to be recognized and acknowledged, rather than a hard idea of a bad feeling.

The direct sensing of the body can also help us to cultivate a calming, clear-sighted, and solid state of mind.

In this program, you will learn different mindfulness exercises that bring awareness to body sensations, such as the Awareness of Breathing. Please follow this practice at least once per day during the next seven days.

We tend to avoid and hide from difficult situations and uncomfortable feelings. Our mind may react to them with resistance, escaping, self-criticism, worry, or anxiety. This automatic defense mechanism of the mind can also empower negative thoughts that may rise and aggravate the problem.

It is not easy, but we recommend that you try to identify these unpleasant feelings and negative thoughts, hold those roadblocks in awareness and consider them for what they are, roadblocks in your journey.

A caring approach is to have a helicopter view of what is happening, avoid taking issues personally, and then look for more helpful ways to improve the situation.

Unpleasant situations always appear in life, bringing unkind impressions to our minds, but we should try to see our negative feelings and thoughts for what they are â€“ our automatic defensive response to the unpleasant moment. Then, after acknowledging and accepting it, we should try to let this state of mind pass, focus on what is good for us, and move beyond the roadblocks to continue our journey.

It is important consider issues that may be distressing the person with dementia, such as:

* Physical discomfort due to illnesses, medication, dehydration, or fatigue
* Delayed reaction to real or imagined trauma
* Frustration due to the failure to communicate effectively
* Complicated tasks, demanding activities, or new chores
* Lack of meaningful and pleasant activities
* Discomfort with the presence of perceived strangers or unfamiliar faces
* Unfamiliar surroundings, such as new places, or the inability to recognize home
* Overstimulation from loud noises or a busy environment, for example, confusion, crowds or clutter
* Other environment factors, such as temperature, brightness, humidity, etc.

If you detect any of these signs, you may want to consult with a doctor, modify the environment, or adapt activities to suit the needs of the person with dementia.

In this context, practical tips to consider include:

* Check glasses and hearing aids to make sure that they are working properly and being used correctly.
* Provide fluids and healthy snacks throughout the day, as the doctor suggests, for proper hydration and nutrition.
* Use weekly pill organizers to help you keep track of medications.
* Provide regular prompts and assistance for bathroom breaks (every 2 hours prevents most accidents)
* Take daily walks and engage in other gentle physical activities to avoid restlessness.
* Make sure the person with dementia stays involved in meaningful activities each day to prevent the occurrence of behavioral problems or the onset of depression.

You also need to take care of yourself, both physically and mentally, so that you prepared for the journey ahead. These are some general strategies that may help you: 
* Exercise, eat healthy foods and see your doctor regularly
* Get outside help as needed
* Take breaks during the day
* Be active socially and spend time with friends
* Engage in pleasant activities, hobbies, and interests
* Maintain your health, legal, and financial information up-to-date

Other practical tips for coping with caregiving include:
* Gain knowledge about dementia
* Join a support group
* Set priorities. Save energy for the â€œmust doâ€ tasks, and delegate tasks to others.
* Get accurate information about your loved oneâ€™s level of functioning and plan accordingly.
* Donâ€™t argue or try to rationalize through a problematic situation with a person with dementia.
* Accept that bad days do happen. It is not your fault when your efforts donâ€™t always pay off. 
* â€œGood enough for nowâ€ results are really good enough. There is much about this disease that canâ€™t be changed or fixed.

We hope that these practical tips may help you to enhance your coping skills.

We recommend that you pay attention to the state of your mind when stressful situations arise. Please try to apply the learning from this program to treat thoughts and emotions with care and respect, but, remember that thoughts are just thoughts that can appear and disappear. Although they can influence your mood and feelings, they do not represent your persona, and you have choices on how to deal with your mind swings.
Also, continue with daily mindfulness exercises. Their periodic practice may help you center yourself, ground your balance, and calm your mind. It can be very beneficial to improve your well-being.
We hope that this Caring program has inspired you to focus on being here and now, enjoy the moment, and let go of too many worries of the mind.
Make sure to include some simple practices in your daily routine and always remember to stop, breath, and continue.
We wish you all the best in your journey ahead.
Introduction to Mindfulness Practices

With stopping, we can calm things down within and around us, becoming calm, clear sighted and solid, which can help us to confront our problems.
The objective of stopping is learning to live deeply starts with the art of stopping and looking inside.
Take a breath with awareness, observe, and proceed. This practice takes less than a minute, and it is a refreshing pause that you can build in your day at any time.
Taking just 20 seconds, say to yourself: stop. Notice sensations on the body, sounds, emotions, thoughts, images, and words in your mind. Stop, take a breath, observe, and proceed.

Find the feeling of breathing. Feel the sensations. Scan what you are seeing, listening, smelling, sensing, etc. Without thinking, practice the art of stopping and sensing the world within and around you.
Notice the way the breathing feels to you. Breathe naturally and bring awareness to the breathing in your body. Get to know your own breathing.
This exercise covers five breathing practices. Please choose the ones that you like most and keep practicing every day.
This is practice than can offer comfort and release in the presence of challenging feelings and emotions.
Find a comfortable location, rest, and follow this practice to release tension and stress.
Have a plan for the journey.
its.bo:
Initial Ideas

Caring for a person with dementia Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia (Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia) at home is a difficult task and can become overwhelming at times.

Each day brings new challenges as the caregiver copes with changing levels of ability and new patterns of behavior. Research has shown that caregivers themselves often are at increased risk for depression and illness, especially if they do not receive adequate support from family, friends, and the community.

One of the biggest struggles caregivers face is dealing with the difficult behaviors, such as agitation, repetition, suspicion, confusion, and not recognizing family. Basic activities of daily living, such as dressing, bathing, and eating, also become difficult to manage for both the person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia and the caregiver.

Having a plan for getting through the day can help caregivers cope. Many caregivers have found it helpful to use strategies for dealing with difficult behaviors and stressful situations. Through trial and error you will find that some of the following tips work, while others do not. Each person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia is unique and will respond differently, and each person changes over the course of the disease. Do the best you can, and remind yourself to take breaks.

its.de: Helpful suggestions
its.bo:
Get Prepared

Finding out that a loved one has Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia can be stressful, frightening, and overwhelming. As you begin to take stock of the situation, here are some tips that may help:

  • Ask the doctor any questions you have about Alzheimer’s disease or dementia. Find out what treatments might work best to alleviate symptoms or address behavior problems.
  • Contact organizations such as the Alzheimer’s Association and the Alzheimer’s Disease Education and Referral (ADEAR) Center for more information about the disease, treatment options, and caregiving resources. Some community groups may offer classes to teach caregiving, problem-solving, and management skills. Find a support group where you can share your feelings and concerns. Members of support groups often have helpful ideas or know of useful resources based on their own experiences. Online support groups make it possible for caregivers to receive support without having to leave home.
  • Study your day to see if you can develop a routine that makes things go more smoothly. If there are times of day when the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia is less confused or more cooperative, plan your routine to make the most of those moments. Keep in mind that the way the person functions may change from day to day, so try to be flexible and adapt your routine as needed.
  • Consider using adult day care or respite services to ease the day-to-day demands of caregiving. These services allow you to have a break while knowing that the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia is being well cared for.
  • Begin to plan for the future. This may include getting financial and legal documents in order, investigating long-term care options, and determining what services are covered by health insurance and Medicare.

its.de: Communicating with a person who has Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia
its.bo:
Communication

Trying to communicate with a person who has Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia can be a challenge.

In the early stage of Alzheimer's, your loved one may start having difficulties to recall names of family/friends. Your patience may help the situation.

As the disease progresses, it may become more difficult to identify and recognize sounds, when an approach of accepting their perception may contribute to improve and even to foster a better outcome.

As both understanding and being understood may be difficult, you may want to try these strategies:

  • Choose simple words and short sentences and use a gentle, calm tone of voice.
  • Avoid talking to the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia like a baby or talking about the person as if he or she weren’t there.
  • Minimize distractions and noise—such as the television or radio—to help the person focus on what you are saying.
  • Call the person by name, making sure you have his or her attention before speaking.
  • Allow enough time for a response. Be careful not to interrupt.
  • If the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia is struggling to find a word or communicate a thought, gently try to provide the word he or she is looking for.
  • Try to frame questions and instructions in a positive way.

its.de: While some people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia donâ€™t mind bathing, for others it is a frightening, confusing experience.
its.bo:
Bathing

While some people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia donâ€™t mind bathing, for others it is a frightening, confusing experience. Advance planning can help make bath time better for both of you.

  • Plan the bath or shower for the time of day when the person is most calm and agreeable. Be consistent. Try to develop a routine.
  • Respect the fact that bathing is scary and uncomfortable for some people with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia. Be gentle and respectful. Be patient and calm.
  • Tell the person what you are going to do, step by step, and allow him or her to do as much as possible.
  • Prepare in advance. Make sure you have everything you need ready and in the bathroom before beginning. Draw the bath ahead of time.
  • Be sensitive to the temperature. Warm up the room beforehand if necessary and keep extra towels and a robe nearby. Test the water temperature before beginning the bath or shower.
  • Minimize safety risks by using a handheld showerhead, shower bench, grab bars, and nonskid bath mats. Never leave the person alone in the bath or shower.
  • Try a sponge bath. Bathing may not be necessary every day. A sponge bath can be effective between showers or baths.

its.de: For someone who has Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia, getting dressed presents a series of challenges.
its.bo:
Dressing

For someone who has Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia, getting dressed presents a series of challenges: choosing what to wear, getting some clothes off and other clothes on, and struggling with buttons and zippers. Minimizing the challenges may make a difference.

  • Try to have the person get dressed at the same time each day so he or she will come to expect it as part of the daily routine.
  • Encourage the person to dress himself or herself to whatever degree possible. Plan to allow extra time so there is no pressure or rush.
  • Allow the person to choose from a limited selection of outfits. If he or she has a favorite outfit, consider buying several identical sets.
  • Arrange the clothes in the order they are to be put on to help the person move through the process.
  • Provide clear, step-by-step instructions if the person needs prompting.
  • Choose clothing that is comfortable, easy to get on and off, and easy to care for. Elastic waists and Velcro enclosures minimize struggles with buttons and zippers.

its.de: Some people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia want to eat all the time, while others have to be encouraged to maintain a good diet.
its.bo:
Eating

Eating can be a challenge. Some people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia want to eat all the time, while others have to be encouraged to maintain a good diet.

  • View mealtimes as opportunities for social interaction and success for the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia. Try to be patient and avoid rushing, and be sensitive to confusion and anxiety.
  • Aim for a quiet, calm, reassuring mealtime atmosphere by limiting noise and other distractions.
  • Maintain familiar mealtime routines, but adapt to the person’s changing needs.
  • Give the person food choices, but limit the number of choices. Try to offer appealing foods that have familiar flavors, varied textures, and different colors.
  • Serve small portions or several small meals throughout the day. Make healthy snacks, finger foods, and shakes available. In the earlier stages of dementia, be aware of the possibility of overeating.
  • Choose dishes and eating tools that promote independence. If the person has trouble using utensils, use a bowl instead of a plate, or offer utensils with large or built-up handles. Use straws or cups with lids to make drinking easier.
  • Encourage the person to drink plenty of fluids throughout the day to avoid dehydration.
  • As the disease progresses, be aware of the increased risk of choking because of chewing and swallowing problems.
  • Maintain routine dental checkups and daily oral health care to keep the mouth and teeth healthy.

its.de: Finding activities for a person with dementia can be difficult.
its.bo:
Activities

What to do all day? Finding activities that the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia can do and is interested in can be a challenge. Building on current skills generally works better than trying to teach something new.

  • Don’t expect too much. Simple activities often are best, especially when they use current abilities.
  • Help the person get started on an activity. Break the activity down into small steps and praise the person for each step he or she completes.
  • Watch for signs of agitation or frustration with an activity. Gently help or distract the person to something else.
  • Incorporate activities the person seems to enjoy into your daily routine and try to do them at a similar time each day.
  • Try to include the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia in the entire activity process. For instance, at mealtimes, encourage the person to help prepare the food, set the table, pull out the chairs, or put away the dishes. This can help maintain functional skills, enhance feelings of personal control, and make good use of time.
  • Take advantage of adult day services, which provide various activities for the person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia, as well as an opportunity for caregivers to gain temporary relief from tasks associated with caregiving. Transportation and meals often are provided.

its.de: Incorporating exercise into the daily routine has benefits for both the person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia and the caregiver.
its.bo:
Exercise

Incorporating exercise into the daily routine has benefits for both the person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia and the caregiver. Not only can it improve health, but it also can provide a meaningful activity for both of you to share.

  • Think about what kind of physical activities you both enjoy, perhaps walking, swimming, tennis, dancing, or gardening. Determine the time of day and place where this type of activity would work best.
  • Be realistic in your expectations. Build slowly, perhaps just starting with a short walk around the yard, for example, before progressing to a walk around the block.
  • Be aware of any discomfort or signs of overexertion. Talk to the person’s doctor if this happens.
  • Allow as much independence as possible, even if it means a less-than-perfect garden or a scoreless tennis match.
  • See what kinds of exercise programs are available in your area. Senior centers may have group programs for people who enjoy exercising with others. Local malls often have walking clubs and provide a place to exercise when the weather is bad.
  • Encourage physical activities. Spend time outside when the weather permits. Exercise often helps everyone sleep better.

its.de: As the disease progresses, many people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia begin to experience incontinence.
its.bo:
Incontinence

As the disease progresses, many people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia begin to experience incontinence, or the inability to control their bladder and/or bowels. Incontinence can be upsetting to the person and difficult for the caregiver. Sometimes incontinence is due to physical illness, so be sure to discuss it with the personâ€™s doctor

  • Have a routine for taking the person to the bathroom and stick to it as closely as possible. For example, take the person to the bathroom every 3 hours or so during the day. Don’t wait for the person to ask.
  • Watch for signs that the person may have to go to the bathroom, such as restlessness or pulling at clothes. Respond quickly.
  • Be understanding when accidents occur. Stay calm and reassure the person if he or she is upset. Try to keep track of when accidents happen to help plan ways to avoid them.
  • To help prevent nighttime accidents, limit certain types of fluids—such as those with caffeine—in the evening.
  • If you are going to be out with the person, plan ahead. Know where restrooms are located, and have the person wear simple, easy-to-remove clothing. Take an extra set of clothing along in case of an accident.

its.de: For the exhausted caregiver, sleep canâ€™t come too soon.
its.bo:
Sleep Problems

For the exhausted caregiver, sleep canâ€™t come too soon. For many people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia, however, the approach of nighttime may be a difficult time. Many people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia become restless, agitated, and irritable around dinnertime, often referred to as â€œsundowningâ€ syndrome. Getting the person to go to bed and stay there may require some advance planning.

  • Encourage exercise during the day and limit daytime napping, but make sure that the person gets adequate rest during the day because fatigue can increase the likelihood of late afternoon restlessness.
  • Try to schedule more physically demanding activities earlier in the day. For example, bathing could be earlier in the morning, or large family meals could be at midday.
  • Set a quiet, peaceful tone in the evening to encourage sleep. Keep the lights dim, eliminate loud noises, even play soothing music if the person seems to enjoy it.
  • Try to keep bedtime at a similar time each evening. Developing a bedtime routine may help.
  • Restrict access to caffeine late in the day.
  • Use night-lights in the bedroom, hall, and bathroom if the darkness is frightening or disorienting.

its.de: As the disease progresses, a person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia may experience hallucinations
its.bo:
Hallucinations

As the disease progresses, a person with Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia may experience hallucinations and/or delusions. Hallucinations are when the person sees, hears, smells, tastes, or feels something that is not there. Delusions are false beliefs from which the person cannot be dissuaded.

  • Sometimes hallucinations and delusions are signs of physical illness. Keep track of what the person is experiencing and discuss it with the doctor.
  • Avoid arguing with the person about what he or she sees or hears. Try to respond to the feelings he or she is expressing, and provide reassurance and comfort.
  • Try to distract the person to another topic or activity. Sometimes moving to another room or going outside for a walk may help.
  • Turn off the television set when violent or disturbing programs are on. The person with Alzheimer’s disease or dementia may not be able to distinguish television programming from reality.
  • Make sure the person is safe and does not have access to anything he or she could use to harm anyone.

its.de: A person with dementia may feel agitated at times. He or she may be restless and move or pace around.
its.bo:
Agitation

A person with dementia may feel anxious or agitated at times. He or she may be restless and move or pace around. The person may become upset in certain places or fixated on specific details, or become very dependent on a certain caregiver for attention.

Some ideas for dealing with this situation:

  • Try to find out what may be causing the anxiety. You can learn to look for early signs of agitation or anxiety and deal with the trigger before the behavior starts.
  • Sometimes this behavior is related to the personâ€™s diet. Limit caffeine and sugar intake and junk foods.
  • Use calming tone and words. Let the individual know that you can help. For example, you can say, 'May I help you?' 'Youâ€™re safe here.' 'I amm sorry that you are upset.'
  • Engage the person in activities. Try using art, music or other activities to help the person relax.
  • Modify or leave the current environment.. You may need to close the windows or adjust the lighting, or move to a different location.
  • The person may be feeling bored. He or she may be looking for something to do. Take a walk, or go for a car ride. Find a pleasant activity for the person.
  • Be mindful if your own stress and worries may be affecting the person you care for.

its.de: A person with dementia may do or say something over and over again
its.bo:
Repetition

A person with dementia may do or say something over and over again â€“ like repeating a word, question or activity. In most cases, he or she is probably seeking security and familiarity.

The person may also undo what has just been finished. These actions are rarely harmful to the person with dementia but can be stressful for the caregiver.

These are some practical tips:

  • Try to find out if there is a specific cause or trigger for this repeating behavior.
  • Try to stay calm and patient. Reassure the person calmly, and sometimes he or she will respond positively to a gentle touch.
  • Focus on the emotion behind the behavior.Instead of reacting to what the person is doing, try think about how he or she is feeling.
  • Engage him or her in an activity, or turn the action or behavior into one. For example, if the person keeps rubbing his or her hand across the table, hand them a cloth and ask for help with wiping. Once the person has something to do, they will less likely to be bored.
  • If the person asks the same questions over and over again, use memory aids, such as leaving notes, using clocks, calendars or photographs, if these items are still meaningful to the individual.
  • Find ways to work with the behavior. Let it be if it doesnâ€™t harm him or herself or others.

its.de: Memory loss and confusion may cause the person with dementia to become suspicious of those around them.
its.bo:
Suspicion

Memory loss and confusion may cause the person with dementia to perceive things in new, unusual ways.

Individuals may become suspicious of those around them. They may accuse others of theft or other improper behavior. Misinterpreting things that he or she sees and hears may also happen.

You may want to try these strategies:

  • Arguing or trying to convince the person typically won’t help and will likely make things worse. Most importantly, don’t take offense. Listen to what is troubling the person, and try to understand their reality and ensure that he or she is safe.
  • Share your thoughts with them and offer a simple answer. Lengthy reasoning will only overwhelm the person.
  • Try to distract the person to another topic or activity. For example, moving to another room or doing some chores.
  • Gently touch or hug to comfort the person.
  • Search for missing things to distract the person; then talk about what you found. For example, talk about a photograph or keepsake.
  • If the person is often looking for a specific item, you can try having several of these items available.
  • You can help the person search for the missing item, but while doing so, you can still try to distract the person by talking about what you found. For example, show them the photograph that you found and have a conversation with them about it.

its.de: Confusion is a very common  problem for people with dementia.
its.bo:
Confusion

Confusion is a very common problem for people with dementia. For example, a person with Alzheimer’s Disease may not recognize familiar places, utensils, or simple objects.

The main underlying cause of confusion is the progressive decline of the brain cells. As the disease progresses, the person with dementia may start having more difficulties to understand where they are and what they are supposed to do.

Thes are some suggestions on how to respond:

  • Choose a simple explanation. Don't argue and don't try to convince. Your patience may help the situation.
  • Look for a reason behind the behavior. Sometimes insecurity may be compensated with understanding and reassurance.
  • A gentle approach is recommended. People with dementia live in a different world. Look for a reason behind the behavior.
  • Redirecting the person to a different actitivy may also help in some situations.
  • By taking a deep breath and re-analyzing the situation, you may be able to deal a difficult behavior with less stress.
  • Look from a different perspective. Try to re-evaluate the situation from a more positive perspective, and from there, you may be better prepared to move forward with caregiving.

its.de: People with dementia  may not recognize familiar people, friends or even close family members.
its.bo:
Not Recognizing Family And Friends

People with dementia may not recognize familiar people, friends or even close family members. They may forget relationships, call family members by other names or be unable to recognize their own home.

These situations can be extremely difficult for caregivers and require much patience and understanding.

As reponding to this behavior may be difficult, you may want to try these strategies:

  • Being called by a different name or not being recognized is painful, but please try to remain calm.
  • Don’t overwhelm the person with lengthy statements and reasons. Sometimes, explanations may sound like scolding. So, try to clarify with a firm and simple suggestion, such as, “I think she’s your daughter Nancy.”
  • Photographs, photo albums and other items can help remind the person of important relationships and places.
  • Sometimes, the person with dementia is unsecure. Being kind and reassuring the person may provide comfort and improve the mood.
  • A positive approach with eye contact and gentle touch (if possible) may help to alleviate the situation.
  • Most importantly, try not to take it personally. Remember, dementia causes your loved one to forget, but your love, support and understanding for them will not cease.

its.de: Other resources to learn more about dementia and caregiving
its.bo:
Other Resources

You may want to look at these resources to learn more about Alzheimer's Disease, related dementia, and caregiving:

 

Alzheimer's Association: www.alz.org

 

Alzheimers.gov: www.alzheimers.gov

 

NIH ADEAR: www.nia.nih.gov/health/alzheimers

 

Family Caregiver Alliance: www.caregiver.org

qts.a:
Caring Mind has been designed to help caregivers of someone with dementia to enhance their mindset, learn helpful skills, practice relaxation exercises, and get prepared to deal with difficult situations.

Our goal is to develop a new tool to help families to deal with challenging situations, reduce stress, and improve quality of life.

The educational curriculum of Caring Reponse is based on research by Photozig, Inc. and Stanford University, namely iCare for family caregivers and Coping with Caregiving, which was developed by Dr. Gallagher-Thompson, Dr. Thompson and associates.

There are also practices developed by RenÃ©e Burgard, LCSW, Mindfulness & Health.

We hope that our program will teach skills and help families struggling with dementia caregiving, as it has helped many caregivers in our past research projects.

1) Watch one Lesson per week.

2) Do a "Relax" or "Breathe" Exercise at least once a day.

3) Read the Learn More articles to get prepared.

You may practice exercises daily, so that you could apply them during difficult situations to alleviate stress.

IMPORTANT: please consult with your doctor before doing any exercise of this app.

qts.q: Is there a login or sign-up?
qts.a: The Login or Sign-up is optional, and it allowes the app to save your Favorite/Liked Exercises in the user account.

qts.q: Is there a subscription? What can I do with the subscription?
qts.a:
During field tests, there is no subscription. All content, educational modules and practices are available without subscription.

In the future, the paid subscription will allow you to watch exclusive "Behavior" videos, and have access to all practices.
We recommend allowing notifications for this app, as we will remind you when it is time to practice your Caring Mind skills, to learn about dementia, and follow your next Relaxation exercise.
